brief_description of the content in the: The JetBrains Inspectopedia page describes a rule that checks if delete or update queries in Spring Data are annotated with the @Modifying annotation. If not, an InvalidDataAccessApiUsageException will be thrown.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'modifying-annotation-missing' checks all classes and their methods. If a method name starts with 'update' or 'delete', it asserts that the method is annotated with '@Modifying'. If the method is not annotated with '@Modifying', it generates a message indicating the method and class name, stating that the method must be annotated with '@Modifying' as it is a delete or update query.
PRE_model_validation: The generated rule is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions and does not introduce any new ones. The rule checks for the presence of the @Modifying annotation on methods whose names start with 'update' or 'delete', which aligns with the requirement.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/spring-data-jpa-modifying-annotation
Summary: This page from Baeldung explains the use of the @Modifying annotation in Spring Data JPA. It mentions that the annotation is needed for delete or update queries, which aligns with the rule generated.

2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50757860/spring-data-jpa-modifying-clear-automatically
Summary: This StackOverflow thread discusses the use of the @Modifying annotation in Spring Data JPA and the exception that is thrown when it is missing, which is the InvalidDataAccessApiUsageException. This supports the rule generated.
